Roberta Guaspari.Action: Reacts with visible hurt to a photo of happier times then rips it apart, showing pain and frustration.
Ignores the arguing boys outside her door and stays withdrawn in bed despite their pleas.
Shouts at movers to be careful with the violins, showing concern for the instruments.
Yells loudly on the phone in frustration and anger, displaying emotional distress.
Responds bitterly when Assunta offers reassurance, showing self-doubt and vulnerability.
Immediately reacts energetically and assertively to the movers dropping the crate, telling them to be careful and organizing the situation.
Yells on the phone, demanding information and trying to solve a personal problem, showing persistence but also emotional turbulence.
Appears emotionally overwhelmed and distracted, still in a ratty nightgown while dealing with important matters, suggesting lack of self-care impacting her effectiveness.
Half-smiles and pours herself coffee, showing quiet acceptance of Assunta's bluntness and advice.
Meticulously wraps a present with care and attention despite pressure and criticism from supervisor.
Does not react confrontationally to the supervisor's dismissive remarks at the gift wrap counter.
Tries to politely shake Brian's hand despite misunderstanding his gesture, then quickly recovers and hands over the gift she wrapped.
Smiles at Brian's self-deprecating joke about his book not being read.
Shares her personal struggles candidly with Brian, showing sincerity and trust.
Corrects Brian's assumption gently when he implies her friend was her best friend.
Describes her husband's infidelity with resigned honesty and without bitterness.
Engages in light teasing and friendly banter with Brian, smiling and blushing.
Responds positively and gratefully when Brian offers to help her find a job.
Engages in friendly banter and shows openness to opportunity when Brian offers to connect her with a school job.
Takes a bite of cold fries but notices and comments on their temperature, showing awareness.
Despite personal turmoil (husband’s infidelity), continues to consider new professional opportunities without showing defeat or resignation.
Sits nervously during job interview, admits lack of traditional experience but explains teaching her sons privately.
Nods defeated when told she lacks qualifications for inner city school position.
Expresses confidence that any child can learn violin and commits to teaching discipline.
Insists kids will be committed despite difficult circumstances, emphasizes mutual support among students.
Looks miffed when Dennis laughs at her belief in the students' abilities.
Responds respectfully and gratefully to Janet's uncertain offer and threat of no permanent position.
Gently asks kids not to open violin cases and repeatedly requests they listen.
Clearly loses patience and firmly commands children to stop misbehaving, eventually ejecting a boy from class.
Tries to take control of a noisy, unruly group of fifty excited children, repeatedly instructs them to behave and follow rules despite their initial disobedience.
Initially unable to get immediate compliance from children opening violin cases and playing inappropriately; loses some control before finally calming the group.
Maintains patience and uses calm, firm commands to regain order, taking deep breaths to compose herself and then proceeds to organize the class.
Identifies and discipline a disruptive student by removing him from class, demonstrating assertiveness and willingness to enforce rules.
Kicks out a disruptive student to maintain order.
Challenges De Sean about his dislike for the violin and gives him a chance to stay in class.
Encourages Naeem by helping him hold the violin and praises his playing.
Promotes a future concert to motivate and include students and their families.
Keeps talking and avoids reacting when Brian kisses her neck, showing discomfort but also politeness.
Stops Brian from removing another roller from her hair, asserting her boundaries.
Keeps talking to deflect an unwanted intimate advance, maintaining composure under discomfort.
Stops Brian from removing her hair rollers, asserting control over personal boundaries.
Shows vulnerability and admits uncertainty about new environment and situation with Brian
Attempts a smile despite feeling hurt and frightened after Brian leaves
Engages with her diverse group of students and encourages them in learning violin technique
Politely tries to clarify scheduling issue with Dennis despite his annoyance.
Persistent but remains polite and respectful during conflict over class schedule.
Gently tucks in Lexi and Nick, responds kindly to their questions and worries.
Reassures children about their father and living situation with patience and affection.
Helps Guadalupe by bringing a chair and suggesting she sit to make her comfortable.
Speaks gently and patiently with Naeem about why he missed class and advocates for his participation despite his mother's objections.
Responds respectfully and tries to confront Mrs. Adisa's objections with understanding and an inclusive argument about the value of music for self-esteem.
Does not escalate conflict with Mrs. Adisa and listens quietly after Mrs. Adisa walks away.
Seems distracted and possibly withdrawn when attempting to read at Brian’s house.
Suggests a practical solution by bringing a chair for Guadalupe to sit, showing attentiveness and care.
Confronts Naeem's mother calmly and logically about the value of music education despite cultural objections, demonstrating confidence and advocacy.
Fails to effectively address or change Mrs. Adisa's ideological objections to classical music and cultural relevance, resulting in Naeem leaving the class.
Attempts to contact Brian Turner, looks at family pictures, feels depressed.
Politely tries to enter classroom and explain she is there for violin students but accepts icy treatment without confrontation.
Reluctantly exits classroom without arguing to avoid confrontation in front of children.
Tries to catch up to Janet, discussing teacher agreement and showing concern for order and cooperation.
Attempts to read but gets distracted, tries to reach Brian by phone, shows signs of emotional distress looking at family pictures.
Arrives late for her violin class, tries to argue her case with another teacher in front of the kids but retreats without a confrontation.
Tries to keep up with Janet amidst chaos in the schoolyard, actively following up on arrangements for the violin class.
Addresses disruptive and joking children firmly but explains her expectations and respect for them.
Is willing to pull students out for music lessons despite causing disruption, showing commitment to their learning.
Does not react harshly to Janet's criticism about disruption and extra work for teachers, instead suggests Janet talk to other teachers.
Stands silently after Janet walks away without a supportive response or further engagement.
Corrects Guadalupe's violin position promptly when she notices the mistake.
Calmly manages household tasks while handling an emotionally difficult phone call.
Shows emotional vulnerability and openness during the phone call about her husband, despite the personal pain.

Expresses vulnerability and emotional pain openly during phone conversation, shows sincere frustration and heartbreak.
Lies awake, emotionally affected by personal problems but still cares for children by watching over them while they sleep.
Considers quitting teaching due to feeling unsuccessful with children, but does not act on it immediately, indicating internal struggle rather than abandonment.
Expresses willingness to quit teaching mid-term due to lack of progress with students and personal distress.
Shows emotional vulnerability and agitation but ultimately continues to engage in conversation and face difficult realities.
Waits patiently for a chance to speak during a tense confrontation, showing restraint.

Puts the violin gently into its case while looking at Guadalupe sadly, expressing empathy.
Tells Guadalupe not to quit something just because it's hard and encourages inner strength.
Accepts an awkward hug from Guadalupe and reacts with touching tenderness, showing emotional intelligence.
Inspects a rundown apartment thoroughly and seriously, demonstrating practical capability in assessing living conditions.
Briefly hesitates and avoids further explanation when asked about personal life (no husband, no boyfriend), showing reserve but not incompetence.

Expresses self-doubt about fitting in and her position in the school.

Shows humor and lightheartedness in response to challenges and conflicts.
Doubts her own job security and future in the program.
Reassures Nick by telling him his father loves him and Lexi very much despite the separation.
Struggles emotionally to explain difficult adult matters to Nick, showing vulnerability and care.
Looks disgusted by the kids' poor violin playing and scolds them sharply for not practicing.
Rolls her eyes at De Sean for inconsistent explanations about his hospital visits.
Confronts Lucy about not practicing and threatens removal from the class.
Responds with genuine sympathy and sorrow when Lucy reveals her grandmother died.
Encourages Lucy to do her best after learning about her loss, despite initial strictness.
Waves back to kids warmly but remains internally upset, showing inward emotional sensitivity despite external toughness.
Approaches Naeem and his mother to encourage Naeem's involvement in music despite cultural concerns, uses example of Arthur Ashe to make a point, expresses belief in Naeem's joy playing music.
Watches her sons happily petting puppies, showing appreciation for their happiness.
Tells her sons they all have to take turns cleaning up, shows a sense of family responsibility, but boys ignore her and she quietly resigns.
Screams at the kids during music class.
Speaks confidently and persuasively to Naeem's mother about the importance of music for her son, using a relevant example to challenge the mother's preconceptions.
Observes her children happily interacting with puppies, reflecting attentiveness and awareness of their emotional state.

Attempts to enforce responsibility with her children by telling them to take turns cleaning up, but internally doubts its effectiveness, indicating some lack of control or confidence in managing them.
Screams at the kids while they play violin, showing possible frustration but potentially undermining her capability to lead calmly.
Corrects students firmly, enforcing discipline and technique.
Dismisses a child's question as unimportant and distracts from learning.
Welcomes a new student with realistic expectations and offers additional support without concern for payment.
Quickly arranges resources (spare violin) for the new student, showing preparedness.
Encourages Lucy's creativity by praising her jazz variation and expresses pride.
Instructs the entire class to try Lucy's variation, fostering group participation.
Admits to being harsh but justifies it as discipline necessary for learning.
Responds to criticism about harshness with nod to soften comments.
Offers reluctant supportive feedback to poor student performance.
Encourages kids gently after a poor performance, asks a child to try harder in a kind manner, shows politeness
Responds to kids' comments about her changing attitude by jokingly calling them out but keeps it light and playful
Kisses and hugs her children goodbye at the airport, shows emotional vulnerability and love
Feels deeply lonely after the boys leave, showing vulnerability and emotional openness.
Decorates a small Christmas tree with the boys and keeps the tradition alive alone, showing sentimental attachment and caring nature.
Carefully prepares and drinks eggnog with rum while feeling miserable, demonstrating sincere emotional expression rather than hiding feelings.
Warily approaches the door at the knock, showing cautiousness but quickly welcomes Brian with warmth and passion.
Embraces and kisses Brian passionately upon his return, showing affectionate and sincere friendliness.
Shows skill and confidence in managing home security by double-locking the door upon returning home.
Carefully decorates a small Christmas tree and prepares a festive drink, showing attention to detail and self-care despite emotional loneliness.
Responds cautiously to an unexpected knock on the door, checking through the peephole before opening, indicating prudence and situational awareness.
Feels deep loneliness and emotional distress but does not take proactive steps to change her situation in this moment, reflecting vulnerability.
Shares beer and jokes with Brian, laughs and kisses him, showing friendly and affectionate interaction.
Expresses desire to live in and work in a tough neighborhood despite concerns, showing commitment and sincerity.
Smiles at her mother feeding a hungry neighborhood boy, showing appreciation for kindness and inclusiveness.

Feels guilty after snapping and moves to comfort Assunta.
Speaks positively and protectively about Brian, emphasizing his good qualities and kindness towards her children.
Defensively asserts her desire for Brian to live with her despite Assunta's doubts.
Leads children warmly and encouragingly during music practice, guiding them patiently through a difficult part.
Encourages students positively by gently correcting negative comments and motivating them to believe they can succeed.

Responds to Brian's teasing with anger and sarcasm, withdrawing emotionally and refusing to express affection.
Sweetly teases Brian, engages in light-hearted interaction.
Hires Ernie despite his old age and seeming inefficiency because he needs a job.

Hires an inexperienced worker (Ernie) who is slow but familiar with the wiring, justifying it due to financial constraints and his past experience.
Chooses to use cheap labor (ex-cons) rather than union workers to save money, resulting in rough construction work (sheetrock with wallpaper), drawing criticism from Brian.
Acknowledges the financial hardship realistically ('this house is taking every penny of my settlement') and tries to manage within constraints.

Takes a deep breath to steady herself before turning back to the children who are watching her, showing composure under pressure.

Responds promptly and sensitively to Rachel’s distress about moving because of family violence, showing emotional intelligence though not directly related to violin skills.
Thanks Assunta sincerely for sewing her dress and getting her out of bed.
Responds to Assunta's critical comment about Charles with thoughtful contemplation rather than defensiveness or anger.
Holds up hands to quiet anxious students, guides them to breathe deeply and encourages them to 'play with your heart' and not be afraid.
Engages with children playfully and patiently, making a learning moment fun by joking about 'frog hair'.
Encourages inclusivity by allowing a boy to answer first despite a girl’s eagerness to respond.
Effectively engages young students by using humor and interactive questioning to teach them about the violin bow.
Manages classroom dynamics confidently by encouraging a student to answer before others interject.
Leads a large and impactful music program teaching approximately 150 students annually despite lack of official public funding.
Continues fundraising efforts after initial funds are depleted to sustain her program, showing persistence and strategic planning.
